question:
A 45-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department because of progressive neck pain for 3 days. He also reports headaches and numbness in both hands. Over the past 4 months, he has had intermittent lower back pain after waking up. The back pain improves with movement. He also has recurrent episodes of gout in the metatarsophalangeal joint of his right big toe. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks four beers daily. The patient is a known user of intravenous heroin. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. There are several track marks on both forearms. Examination of the neck shows warmth, erythema, and limited range of motion. Gentle palpation over the midcervical spinal processes causes severe pain. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,200/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 77%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 278,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 54 mm/h
Blood cultures are pending. An x-ray of the cervical spine shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the spine shows signs of inflammation. A bone biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
predict: {"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient presents with progressive neck pain, headaches, numbness in both hands, and a history of recurrent gout, which suggests a systemic illness. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results indicate a possible infection. The patient's fever, elevated leukocyte count, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate support this suspicion. The MRI of the spine shows signs of inflammation, but no abnormalities on the x-ray. The bone biopsy confirms the diagnosis. The patient's history of intravenous heroin use increases the risk of osteomyelitis or other infections. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest a diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to start specific antibiotic therapy for osteomyelitis. Among the options provided, intravenous ciprofloxacin and vancomycin therapy is the most appropriate choice, as it covers a broad spectrum of bacteria, including Staphylococcus aureus, which is a common cause of osteomyelitis. Additionally, vancomycin has good penetration into bone tissue, making it a suitable choice for osteomyelitis. Lumbar puncture may be considered if there is suspicion of meningitis, but it is not indicated in this case. Oral indomethacin is not the primary treatment for osteomyelitis, although it may be used to manage pain and inflammation. Bone scintigraphy is a diagnostic tool, but it is not a therapeutic intervention. ", "answer_choice": "B"}
